Course Section: CAPS_V 423-001 - Human Renal and Gastrointestinal Physiology
Course Section Definition Public Notes: Location: LSC 1410.

Gender and Nation in European Literatures 

Cross-listed with GMST 517A. This course is focused on concepts of “nation-building” in central, eastern and northern Europe in relation to discourses of personal and political Emancipation, Enlightenment, as well as Orientalism. It falls into four modules: (1) Concepts of “Nation” in Canada and Europe, focusing on narrative prose between Canadian First Nations as well as German ad Russian perspectives. (2) Emancipation, Revolution and “Nation”, focusing on political poetry of the 1848-revolution in central Europe. (3) Enlightenment, Race, Religion and “Nation” focusing on 18th century plays about crusades, colonialism, slavery and gender (4) Gender Politics and “Nation” around 1900, focusing on plays with military definitions of ‘nation-states’ and the role of officers’ daughters. 

This course has no prerequisites. Language of instruction is English. All course materials will be provided on Canvas. It is offered in a once-a-week workshop format, and both at the undergraduate (CENS 404) and graduate levels (GMST 517A). This class is taught in mixed-mode of in-person and online meetings and assignments. Remote participation via Zoom is possible. Please inquire with instructor.

CHIN_V 401-011 - Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Placement Procedure -Prior to registration in any CHIN-titled courses, students are required to complete the Placement Procedure every Winter session or Summer Session and obtain a placement approval certificate for the courses they wish to register for. Students are only eligible for courses listed on their placement approval certificate. Students enrolled in sections which they do not have placement approval for will be removed from the course.

Delivery Mode -This course has 3 instructional hrs/wk in person, 1.5 hours on Tuesday and 1.5 hrs on Thursday, both conducted synchronously. For further information regarding CHIN courses, please go to https://chinese.arts.ubc.ca/courses/ .

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.
